Woolly Mammoth: The Woolly Mammoth is a fascinating extinct animal that I would love to bring back to life. It was a large mammal that lived during the Pleistocene epoch and was covered in fur. It would be amazing to see this majestic creature roam the earth once again and experience the wonder of seeing it in its natural habitat.

Tasmanian Tiger: The Tasmanian Tiger is another extinct animal that I would love to bring back to life. It was a marsupial that lived in Australia and Tasmania and was known for its distinctive stripes. It would be incredible to see this rare and beautiful animal in action and observe its behavior in the wild.

Dodo: The Dodo is a bird that became extinct on the island of Mauritius in the 17th century. It was a flightless bird that was known for its unique appearance and its inability to fly. I would love to bring it back to life and observe its behavior in its natural habitat, and see how it has adapted to life without flight.

Woolly Rhino: The Woolly Rhino was a large mammal that lived in Africa and Asia during the Pleistocene epoch. It was covered in fur and had a horn on its head, which made it a target for hunters. I would love to bring it back to life and observe its behavior in the wild, and see how it has adapted to life without the threat of hunters.

Giant Panda: The Giant Panda is an extinct animal that lived in China during the Pleistocene epoch. It was a large bear that was covered in fur and had a distinctive black and white coloration. I would love to bring it back to life and observe its behavior in the wild, and see how it has adapted to life in China's forests.
